title: Protocol to analyze circulating small non-coding RNAs by high-throughput RNA sequencing from human plasma samples
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Collection of human peripheral blood and plasma isolation and storage
Timing: 2 h maximum
This step describes how to properly isolate plasma from human whole blood in order to avoid pre-analytical biases leading to discrepancies in the downstream analyses.
Draw blood using BD vacutainer Safety-Lok butterflies in order to avoid hemolysis of blood samples. For sncRNA analysis, blood should be collected in K3 or K2-EDTA Vacutainer tubes (suggested: BD Vacutainer K2-EDTA tubes, 3.0 mL).
Invert K2-EDTA Vacutainer tubes 10 times. Blood tubes can be stored upright at room temperature (15°C–25°C) for maximum 2 h.
Process blood samples to isolate plasma within 2 h from blood draw, according to the following steps:
Centrifuge blood containing K2-EDTA Vacutainer tubes at 1800×g for 10 min at room temperature.
Note: at this stage, centrifuging at room temperature is important in order to avoid platelet activation (Tablin et al., 2000[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib18]). Activated platelets can release microvesicles containing sncRNAs thus biasing the original content of the sample (Diehl et al., 2012[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib5]; Xia et al., 2018[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib22]).
Note: blood processing at 4°C appears to be attractive, because enzymatic degradation processes are reduced at low temperatures. However, platelets become activated at low temperatures (as reported in Tablin et al., 2000[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib18]) and release intracellular proteins, enzymes and microvesicles-containing small RNAs, which significantly affect samples composition. Thus, blood processing at low temperatures should be performed only after platelets removal. Since one centrifugation step may not be enough for depletion of platelets below 10 cells/mL, a second centrifugation step [usually between 1,200–2,500×g for 15 min at room temperature (in our protocol 1200g×g for 20 min)] or filtration step may be required to obtain platelet poor plasma.
Transfer the plasma layer into a nuclease- and pyrogen-free tube (Eppendorf style) for second centrifugation.

Note: Plasma should be transferred in a way to avoid possible contamination. Please wear lab coats and gloves, carefully clean the work bench before and after, with an appropriate cleaner (EtOH 70% and RNAse ZAP-like solution). Please, use nuclease-free sterilized filter tips (RNase-, DNase-, DNA- and pyrogen-free) ensuring the use of clean pipettes, change the pipette filter tip after each sample when collecting plasma; be aware not to touch the buffy coat layer with pipette tip in order to avoid blood cell contamination.
Collect plasma in a 2.0 mL sterile and nuclease-free tube (Eppendorf style tube) (Expected 600 μL to 1 mL of plasma for a total of 3–5 aliquots depending on the initial blood sample volume).
Check plasma and note state, as shown in Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2].
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/732-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. Plasma state
Picture showing normal and hemolyzed plasma samples collected in a 2.0 mL tube after the first centrifuge.
Centrifuge collected plasma samples at 1200×g for 20 min at 10°C.
Note: this second centrifugation step is necessary to remove eventual contaminant cells, cell debris and remaining platelets (Shin et al., 2017[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib16]; Zheng et al., 2013[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib23]).
Collect plasma aliquots (220 μL) into new nuclease-free sterile collection tubes and temporarily store them on ice while transferring to −80°C freezer.
Store plasma aliquots at −80°C until use.
Please, refer to Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3] for a rapid overview of blood collection and plasma isolation protocol.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/732-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Blood collection and processing workflow
Following plasma isolation, hemolysis rate should be evaluated, according to the following steps (Shah et al., 2016[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib15]):
Using a drop spectrophotometer (e.g., Nanodrop, Nanovue, etc.), read the plasma (2 μL) absorbance at 414 nm wavelength (hemoglobin absorbance peak).
If absorbance is lower than 0.072 absorbance unit (AU), the sample is not considered hemolyzed.

If absorbance is comprised between 0.072 and 0.3 AU it could be low-moderate hemolyzed. In this case, consider including it in your analysis with reserve to further check the small RNAs profile upon sequencing for relevant global changes of small RNAs.
If absorbance is higher than 0.3 AU, the sample is highly hemolyzed and should be excluded from further analysis.
Critical: aliquots should be prepared by considering a volume of 220 μL (10% volume excess). Multiple aliquots from the same plasma sample should be prepared in order to avoid freeze-thaw cycles, which affect sncRNA stability and the following recovery and analyses. Plasma aliquots must be transferred and stored at −80°C to preserve RNA integrity (Sourvinou et al., 2013[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib17]).
Critical: it is important to process plasma samples within 2 hours from collection since the expression of some miRNAs could be modified in a time-dependent fashion (e.g., miR-15b and miR-191) (Khan et al., 2017[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib10]).
Critical: EDTA tubes are absolutely preferred to other anticoagulants. Indeed, heparin should be avoided due to its ability to inhibit enzymes used in downstream reactions, thus leading to miRNAs expression modifications. Additionally, sodium citrate is not recommended due to its ability to enhance sensitivity to hemolysis (Cui et al., 2011[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib4]; Khan et al., 2017[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib10]).
RNA extraction
Timing: 1 h 30 min
RNA extraction is performed from 200 μL of plasma using Plasma/Serum RNA Purification Mini Kit from Norgen (see Key Resource Table) following manual’s instructions (https://norgenbiotek.com/sites/default/files/resources/Plasma-Serum-RNA-Purification-Kit-PI55000-5.pdf[href=https://norgenbiotek.com/sites/default/files/resources/Plasma-Serum-RNA-Purification-Kit-PI55000-5.pdf]) with minor modifications.

Optimal and best performing RNA extraction method was selected among three different candidate protocols following an explorative sncRNA sequencing experiment performed on plasma samples deriving from a healthy subject. Briefly, total RNA was extracted from 200 μL of human plasma using n=3 different RNA extraction kits (200 μL/each kit): a) Advanced miRNeasy, b) Machery-Nagel and c) Norgen. sncRNA libraries were generated through QIASEQ miRNA library kit, and subsequently sequenced using MiSeqDX platform. In details, data analyses showed that all RNA extraction kits were able to generate sncRNA libraries (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]A). Sequencing primary analysis revealed that Machery-Nagel resulted in 4.07×106reads/sample, Norgen libraries returned 3.91×106 reads/sample and Advanced MiRNeasy resulted in 3.55×106reads/sample (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B). Among total reads, Machery-Nagel resulted in 26% of mapped miRNAs (normalized ratio on total reads), Norgen returned 44% miRNAs composition rate and Advanced MiRNeasy returned 49% miRNAs (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]C). In this set of experiments, both Norgen and Advanced MiRNeasy kits outperformed similarly, then they can be both adopted in this workflow. In our standardized protocol, we adopted Norgen kit and further described its specific procedure below.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/732-Fig4.jpg
Figure 4. RNA extraction kits
Figure showing the results of small RNA sequencing on RNA extracted from plasma (200 μL) of a single human healthy subject with n=3 different RNA extraction kits. (A) Bioanalyzer electropherograms showing profiles of libraries generated using miRNeasy Advanced protocol (Average peak 175 bp), Machery-Nagel protocol (Average peak 183 bp) and Norgen protocol (Average peak 182 bp). Sequencing primary analysis revealed that (B) Machery-Nagel RNA libraries resulted in 4.07×106 reads; Advanced miRNeasy RNA libraries resulted in 3.55×106 reads and Norgen RNA libraries resulted in 3.91×106 reads. Among total reads (C) Machery Nagel enriched for 26% of miRNAs, Advanced miRNeasy enriched for 49% miRNAs, and Norgen enriched for 44% miRNAs. This latter was chosen as RNA extraction protocol.

Thaw plasma samples (200 μL) on ice.
Note: Complete thawing of a 200 μL plasma aliquot on ice requires approximately 30 minutes.
Prepare complete Lysis Buffer A: warm Lysis Buffer A (included in the Norgen kit) at 60°C for at least 20 min to dissolve eventual precipitates. When at room temperature, add 10 μL of β-Mercaptoethanol for each mL of Lysis Buffer A.
Critical: Please ensure that Lysis Buffer A is completely resuspended, and no further precipitate is visible before proceeding. An uncomplete resuspension of Lysis Buffer A as well as non-addition of β-Mercaptoethanol could result into an inefficient lysis leading to a low RNA recovery. See Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5] for a complete resuspended Lysis Buffer A working solution.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/732-Fig5.jpg
Figure 5. Norgen Lysis Buffer A
Norgen Lysis Buffer A working solution should appear clear, transparent and without precipitates before proceeding to RNA extraction.
Centrifuge plasma samples 400×g for 2 min at room temperature before processing.
Note: this step is critical to further remove cell debris and larger particles from plasma samples.
Transfer 200 μL of centrifuged plasma sample into a new 2.0 mL tube (sterile, nuclease-free, pyrogen-free).
Add a volume of 600 μL of Lysis Buffer A + β-Mercaptoethanol. Mix well by vortexing for 10 s.
Add 800 μL of 96–100% ethanol. Mix well by vortexing for 10 s.
Transfer 650 μL of the resulting mixture into a Micro Spin column (included in Norgen kit). Centrifuge 3,300×g for 2 min. Discard the flow-through and reassemble the spin column with its collection tube.
Repeat this step twice more, until the whole mixture has been transferred to the Micro Spin column.
Add 400 μL of Wash Solution A to the column and centrifuge for 30 s at 3,300×g; discard the flow-through and reassemble the spin column with its collection tube.

Repeat this step twice more, for a total of three washes.
Spin the column, empty, for 2 min at 13,000×g. Discard the collection tube.
Transfer the spin column to a fresh 1.5 mL elution tube.
Elute by adding 20 μL of Elution Solution A to the column and let stand at room temperature for 2 min.
Centrifuge for 1 min at 400×g, followed by 2 min at 5,800×g.
Transfer the eluted volume back to the column and let stand at room temperature for 2 min.
Centrifuge for 1 min at 400×g, followed by 2 min at 5,800×g.
Approximately, a final eluted volume of 18 μL should be present in the tube.
Maintain the tube on ice until storage at −80°C.
Note: it is not helpful to quantify extracted total RNA from 200 μl of human plasma samples since the absolute quantity is generally too low for commonly used RNA quantification methods (e.g., Spectrophotometer, Spectrofluorometer or capillary electrophoresis) (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/732-Fig6.jpg
Figure 6. Bioanalyzer 2100 electropherograms
Bioanalyzer 2100 electropherograms showing (A) the enrichment of sncRNA species (blue rectangle) in RNA extracted from 50 μL of murine plasma, (B) undetectability (below detection limit and similar to a negative CTR) of sncRNA species in RNA extracted from 50 μL of human plasma (blue rectangle). In order to consistently quantify (ng) circulating sncRNA species in human plasma samples, RNA should be extracted at least from 1.0 mL of human plasma (C).
SncRNA library preparation and quality controls (QCs)
Timing: 2 days for 8–16 samples/each lab operator

In this section, we describe a systematic protocol to prepare sncRNA libraries using Qiaseq miRNAs Library kit (see Key Resource Table[href=https://www.wicell.org#key-resources-table]) following manufacturer’s instructions (https://www.qiagen.com/us/resources/resourcedetail?id=f0b9d117-f8c6-4825-9069-3236ed65521d[href=https://www.qiagen.com/us/resources/resourcedetail?id=f0b9d117-f8c6-4825-9069-3236ed65521d]) with modifications. This library preparation kit was chosen based on the large use of QIASeq MicroRNA kit reported in literature, where it is reported as the most performant kit (Heinicke et al., 2020[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib9]) (Wong et al., 2019[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib21]), as well as based on a previous set of experiments on murine plasma samples, aimed at comparing different sncRNAs library preparation kits, and showing that QIASeq returned the best results in terms of quality and yield (data not shown).
The following protocol (see Summarizing scheme below) is designed for optimal preparation of eight samples/reaction. Based on our experience we suggest processing no more than sixteen samples/reaction, since some steps require quick and straightforward handling; however, here we consider libraries preparations standardized on 8 samples/reaction. Delays in completing some steps (e.g., cDNA cleanup) significantly affect the quality of cDNA libraries preparation.
table:files/protocols_protocol_732_2.csv
Perform 3′ Adapter ligation reaction (for 8 samples) as follows:
Thaw at room temperature: 3′ Adapter, 3′ Buffer, 2× Ligation Activator (located at −20°C) and then resuspend the reagents by flicking and briefly centrifuging the tubes.
Thaw RNA samples on ice, resuspend them by flicking, and briefly centrifuge the tubes; then put RNA samples on ice.
Dilute 3′ Adapter 1:5 in a 0.5 mL tube: 2 μL 3′ Adapter + 8 μL nuclease-free water (keep at room temperature). Spin down, resuspend up and down (15 times) with pipette volume set to 8 μL and spin down again.
Prepare 3′ Adapter ligation mix on ice and add components according to the following order:
table:files/protocols_protocol_732_3.csv
aFinal volumes include a 5% excess calculation.

bNote: The input RNA volume is 5 μL/18 μL of total eluted RNA per sample. Increasing input RNA quantity by performing a Speedvac (10 minutes room temperature) step (18 μL→5 μL) of the total eluted RNA, in order to load the entire volume of extracted RNA, did not improve sncRNA libraries yield, QC, sequencing metrics and reads distribution of Small RNA species (Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]).
Briefly centrifuge, pipette up and down 15 times with a micropipette set to 120 μL, centrifuge again.
Prepare 2 rows of a 96-well plate (Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]A). Use the right-sided row of the well plate and mark it with a pen marker. Place them into a cooler (Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]B).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/732-Fig7.jpg
Figure 7. Reads distribution
Stacked bars showing reads distribution of small RNA libraries generated from 5 μL of RNA concentrated through Speedvac vacuum centrifuge extracted from plasma of n=28 healthy subjects. MiRNAs are the more represented species of small RNA, corresponding to a mean of 23.6%.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/732-Fig8.jpg
Figure 8. Plates preparation
(A) Before cutting the 2 rows from the plate, apply a PCR adhesive film on it in order to avoid contamination.
(B) 2 rows of a 96 well plate prepared for 3′ Adapter ligation reaction for 8 samples. Place the 2 rows in a thermo cooler rack in order to keep a low temperature of the reactions.
Add 15 μL/well of MIX to the bottom of the well.
Add 5 μL of RNA sample per well.
Resuspend 15 times with multichannel micropipette set to a 10 μL volume.
Cap with a row of strips and briefly spin down.
Start the reaction according to the following thermal cycler steps:
table:files/protocols_protocol_732_4.csv
Critical: this reaction is very viscous due to the Ligation activator reagent. Pipette slowly and carefully.

Critical: the efficiency of the thermal cycler may affect the yield of the libraries. For the present protocol we adopted the SimpliAmp thermal cycler (see Key Resource Table) with the following specifications: 96-well 0.2 mL Veriflex Block; Max block Ramp rate: 4°C/second; Max sample ramp rate: 3°C/sec; Temperature accuracy: ± 0.25°C (35.0°C–99.9°C); Temperature Uniformity: <0.5°C.
Critical: in order to avoid contamination between samples and libraries, it is essential to clean gloves with 70% EtOH every time you cap and uncork the wells with the strips. Maintain this caution for all libraries preparation steps.
Note: for all reactions, enzymes should be thawed at the time of use and immediately put on ice.
Perform 5′ Adapter ligation reaction (for 8 samples) as follows:
Thaw at room temperature the 5′ Adapter and 5′ Buffer reagents. Bring them to room temperature. Resuspend and spin down.
Dilute 5′ Adapter 1:2.5 in a 0.5 mL tube: 4 μL 5′ Adapter + 6 μL nuclease-free water. Resuspend 15 times by pipette with volume set to 8 μL and spin down again.
Prepare reaction mix on ice and add components according to the following order:
table:files/protocols_protocol_732_5.csv
aFinal volumes include a 5% excess calculation.
Pipette 15 times with multichannel pipette volume set to 140 μL.
Remove 3′ Ligation reactions from thermal cycler, briefly spin down and place back into cooler.
Uncork the strip from 3′ Ligation reactions and add 20 μL of MIX to each well.
Resuspend 15 times with 30–300 μL multichannel pipette with volume set to 35 μL.
Cap again with a new strip, briefly spin down and start the reaction according to the following thermal cycler steps:
table:files/protocols_protocol_732_6.csv
Critical: in order to avoid freezing of samples, remember (from this reaction onward) to put 96-well thermal cooler at room temperature few minutes before starting the reaction.

Prepare and activate beads (for 8 samples) as follows:
Take DynaMag2 Magnet (16 positions for 2.0 mL tubes).
Take Beads bottle and Beads Binding Buffer bottle (both at +4°C).
Consider 400 μL beads/sample×8 = 3,200 μL to distribute in 2 × 2.0 mL tubes (1,600 μL/each tube).
Vortex bottle beads for about 1 min.
Add 1,600 μL of beads into the first tube by making two 800 μL pipettings (pipette slowly).
Vortex the beads bottle again for about 30 s and add another 1,600 μL into the second tube by performing two pipettings of 800 μL (pipette slowly).
Place the 2 tubes into the Dynamag2 magnet. The beads will migrate in about 15–20 min.
Briefly vortex the Bead Binding Buffer.
Remove the supernatant from the beads with the p1000 set to 800 μL, very slowly and with the tubes still on the magnet. Be sure not to remove the beads and make sure the beads have fully migrated.
Remove the tubes from the magnet and add 600 μL of Beads Binding Buffer (150 μL Beads Binding Buffer/sample: ×4/tube = 600 μL /each tube from 2.0 mL) directly onto the beads.
Vortex the two tubes for about 1 min at high speed and briefly spin down.
Place the two tubes back on the magnet for about 10–12 min or until the beads have migrated.
Remove the supernatant very slowly avoiding taking beads away (check the tip).
Vortex the Beads Binding Buffer.
Pull the tubes away from the magnet.
Add 1,600 μL of Bead Binding Buffer/sample (400 μL Beads Binding Buffer/sample: ×4/× tube = 1,600 μL/each tube from 2.0 mL) directly onto the beads.
Vortex until the beads are homogeneously resuspended (example in Figure 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig9]) and store at +4°C.

Critical: in order to avoid carry away beads thus modifying their concentration, leave a minimal liquid volume in the first step of supernatant elimination following beads complete migration. Also avoid letting beads go into the cap; if they do go into the cap briefly spin down.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/732-Fig9.jpg
Figure 9. Beads resuspension state
Pictures show different levels of beads resuspension.
(A) Beads not resuspended not usable for cleanup.
(B) Beads not completely resuspended showing a small pellet, not usable for cleanup.
(C) Beads completely resuspended usable for cleanup.
Note: prepared and activated beads can be stored at +4°C and used within 1 week.
Perform Reverse transcription (RT) initiation reaction:
Thaw at room temperature RT Initiator reagent, resuspend by flicking and briefly spin down.
Thaw the following reagents: RT Buffer, RT Primer, resuspend and briefly spin down.
Take the 5′ Ligation reaction out of the thermal cycler and briefly spin down. Store into a thermal cooler.
Remove the strips from the wells and add 2 μL of RT Initiator/Sample.
Resuspend 15 times with multichannel micropipette set to 35 μL.
Put new strips and briefly spin down; start the reaction according to the following thermal cycler steps:
table:files/protocols_protocol_732_7.csv
Note: RT Buffer and RT Primer could be thawed together with RT initiator; indeed, since RT initiation reaction takes circa 20 minutes, in this time the operator can start to dilute RT primers and to prepare RT mix for the following reaction.
Perform RT reaction:
Dilute RT Primer 1:5 in nuclease-free water. For 8 samples: 4 μL RT Primers + 16 μL nuclease-free water; resuspend for 15 times and briefly spin down.
Prepare RT MIX (for 8 samples) and maintain it on ice:
table:files/protocols_protocol_732_8.csv
aFinal volumes include a 5% excess calculation.
Resuspend 15 times with a multichannel pipette with volume set to 140 μL.

Remove RT Initiator reactions from the thermal cycler, spin down, place it back into a cooler and remove strips.
Add 18 μL of RT mix/sample.
Resuspend 15 times with multichannel pipette set to 53 μL.
Strip the tubes, spin down and start the reaction according to the following thermal cycler steps:
table:files/protocols_protocol_732_9.csv
Perform cDNA cleanup:
Freshly prepare 80% EtOH in nuclease-free sterile water.
Vortex beads for at least 1 min at a low vortex speed.
From now on work at room temperature. Add 143 μL of previously activated beads/well. Vortex beads every 2 wells.
Resuspend 20 times with multichannel micropipette set at 190 μL and incubate 5 min at room temperature.
Place samples to the 96-well magnet and do not remove until the end of the procedure.
Incubate 15 min to allow complete migration of the beads.
Add 5.0 mL of 80% EtOH into the reservoirs and remove supernatant with multichannel micropipette set at 190 μL. Aspirate slowly and leave a small volume.
Add 200 μL 80% EtOH/sample.
Recover all 80% EtOH with volume set to 200 μL and repeat step h. and i.
Cap with strips. Very briefly spin down and put back on magnet 1 min.
Aspirate remaining volume with 10 μL multichannel pipette (several times if needed).
Perform air dry 10–12 min (beads drying shown in Figure 10[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig10]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/732-Fig10.jpg
Figure 10. Beads drying state
This picture shows 3 different levels of beads drying. From right to left: those named ‘cracked beads’ are too much dried and cannot further be considered to elute the sample; those named ‘wet beads’ have not yet completely dried, thus containing ethanol which can influence sequencing analyses; those named ‘dry beads’ are completely dried but not cracked and are perfect to be hydrated with water to perform elution step.

Add 17 μL of nuclease-free water directly onto the beads (without touching them with the tip).
Remove from magnet and resuspend by pipetting 20 times.
Incubate 2 min at room temperature.
Place back on magnet for 2 min.
Recover 15 μL/sample and transfer to another sterile well of 96 wells plate (as previously shown in Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]).
Critical: do not pass with anything (pipette, hands, etc.) over the reservoir containing EtOH; if EtOH is contaminated, also libraries will be contaminated.
Critical: prepare 10 mL of 80% EtOH, of which 5.0 mL are used for the first cleanup and the remaining 5.0 mL are used for the second cleanup. However, immediately following usage, EtOH-remaining-volume must be para-filmed, otherwise its concentration will be reduced due to evaporation.
Critical: air dry is a critical step, since the not complete dry (which means EtOH-remaining volume) could influence the following sequencing analyses; on the other side, too much dried beads will result in a low libraries recovery and low libraries concentrations.
Pause Point: the eluted material can be stored at −20°C before to proceed to the next step the next day. In our experience, stopping at this step results in a higher libraries concentration (Average 120 nM vs average 30 nM) (Example in Figure 11[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig11]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/732-Fig11.jpg
Figure 11. Quality control of libraries following pause point step
Examples of (A) n=3 electropherograms in which storage at −20°C pause point has been performed following cDNA cleanup and of (B) n=3 electropherograms in which storage at −20°C pause point has not been performed following cDNA cleanup. While libraries profiles were acceptable in both cases, the concentration is strongly reduced without pause point application (mean value w/ −20°C storage: 119,6 nM vs 79,45 Mean w/o −20°C storage).
Perform cDNA amplification:

Thaw at room temperature the Amplification Library Buffer reagent and nuclease-free water (troubleshooting: problem 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.1]).
Thaw Index Plate and place it into the cooler for few minutes. Cut the wells of interest (use fine scissors - e.g., from surgery) (Figure 12[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig12]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/732-Fig12.jpg
Figure 12. Index plate wells cutting
Picture of index plate wells cutting.
Thaw cDNA and place it into the cooler.
Prepare MIX (8 samples) in the following order:
table:files/protocols_protocol_732_10.csv
Resuspend by pipette 15 times with volume set at 185 μL.
Add 25 μL of MIX to each well of the cut index well (DO NOT PIPETTE).
Spin down cDNA samples.
Transfer 15 μL of each cDNA sample to its respective position in the index row.
Resuspend by pipette 25 times with pipette set to 34 μL. Do not spin (no new strips can be inserted).
With the tips still into the wells, set multichannel pipette volume to 42 μL. Transfer to a new well taking care to recover all the volume (repeat with multichannel at 10 μL if necessary).
Put new strips onto the wells, spin down and start the reaction according to the following thermal cycler steps:
table:files/protocols_protocol_732_11.csv
Note: the direction of the index row is indicated by the presence of numbers at the bottom.
Critical: index plate should be left in thermal cooler for some minutes, otherwise the wells could break while being cut.
Critical: indexes corresponding to a specific sample must be annotated, in order to associate each index to a sample for the following sequencing.
Critical: it is necessary (although not planned by manual’s instructions) to transfer the reaction into new wells since caps of provided index plate are not airtight, and, consequently, the reaction could evaporate.
Perform amplification product cleanup:

Pull out prepared and activated beads from +4°C at least 5 min before starting.
Vortex the beads for 1 min to resuspend them and briefly spin down.
Remove amplification reactions from thermal cycler, briefly spin down and put them in a rack at room temperature.
Vortex beads again (vortex high speed for few seconds and then low speed for 1 min).
From now on work at room temperature.
Add 37.5 μL beads/sample (Vortex beads every two samples).
Resuspend 15 times with multichannel pipette set at 70 μL and incubate 5 min at room temperature.
Transfer to the magnet and incubate at least 5 min or until complete migration is achieved.
Recover all the supernatant by setting multichannel micropipette to 80 μL and transfer to new sterile wells placed on the rack. Carefully inspect whether no libraries volume is left in the wells: if necessary, recover the remaining volume with 10 μL multichannel pipette, then throw away beads.
Vortex beads bottle as previously done and add 65 μL beads/sample by vortexing every 2 samples.
Resuspend 15 times with multichannel pipette set at 120 μL and incubate 5 min at room temperature.
Transfer to magnet and incubate for at least 10 min.
Transfer 5.0 mL 80% EtOH into a new sterile reservoir.
Eliminate supernatant from the beads, taking care not to take away the beads, setting pipette to 135 μL.
Add 200 μL 80% EtOH/sample on the opposite side of the beads.
Remove 80% EtOH and add 200 μL 80% EtOH again.
Remove all the volume, cap with new strips and briefly (no more than 1 s) spin down.
Place back the plate on magnet and remove any residual volume.
Air Dry 10–12 min on the magnet.
Add 17 μL nuclease-free water on the beads and remove from magnet.

Resuspend about 20 times, setting pipette to 15 μL and incubate for 2 min at room temperature.
Transfer the plate again onto the magnet for 2 min at room temperature.
Recover 15 μL supernatant and transfer to a new sterile plate.
Maintain samples into the cooler or store the samples at −20°C.
Measure libraries concentration using QUBIT 3.0 spectrofluorometer:
Work with light off.
For each sample prepare working solution by adding 1 μL DNA high sensitivity QUBIT fluorescent reagent to 199 μL DNA high sensitivity QUBIT buffer (if you are going to analyze more samples, always calculate an extra sample for working solution preparation).
Transfer 199 μL working solution into a QUBIT 0.5 mL new sterile tube and add 1 μL of each library; to read the standards, transfer 190 μL working solution into a QUBIT 0.5 mL new sterile tube and add 10 μL of each standard (#1 and #2).
Resuspend, spin down and incubate 2 min at room temperature.
Read samples concentration with the program DNA → High sensitivity, selecting 1 μL as volume (troubleshooting: problem 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.3]).
Note: it is not necessary to read standards every time. It is needed when more than one week from the last read passed, or if last time you have read samples with another kit (RNA, protein, etc.).
Perform libraries quality control (QC) through Bioanalyzer 2100 by using dsDNA high sensitivity kit:
Bring to room temperature all reagents (ladder, marker, gel matrix and dye) at least 30 min before chip loading.
Prepare gel dye mix by adding 15 μL blue dye into 300 μL gel matrix, vortex 30 s and briefly spin down.
Load the prepared gel dye mix onto dedicated filter and centrifuge 2,240×g 10 min.
Prepare empty chip for electrodes wash by adding 450 μL of nuclease-free water.

Remove and discard the filter from gel dye mix prepared tube.
Load 9 μL gel dye mix into the G chip well and perform chip priming (Figure 13[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig13]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/732-Fig13.jpg
Figure 13. Bioanalyzer 2100 dsDNA chip
Picture showing Bioanalyzer 2100 dsDNA chip and different wells to perform chip priming and samples loading. In details, G wells (as indicated in the main text) are marked in pink, G well (as indicated in the main text) for chip priming is marked in red, and ladder well is marked in orange.
Load 9 μL gel dye mix into the G chip wells (n=3) (Figure 13[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig13]).
Load 5 μL marker in every well apart for G wells (n=4).
Load 1 μL samples into the appropriate wells and 1 μL ladder into the well illustrated in Figure 13[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig13].
Wash electrodes by applying wash chip (loaded with nuclease-free water) for 1 min, closing the instrument door; then allow electrodes to dry by leaving open the instrument door for 1 min.
Meanwhile vortex the loaded chip for 1 min into the appropriate IKA MS3 vortex At 2400 RPM.
Load the chip onto the instrument.
Start the run.
For specific results see “expected outcomes[href=https://www.wicell.org#expected-outcomes]” section (troubleshooting: problem 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.5])
Critical: chip priming is an essential and critical step; plunger should return to at least 0.3 mL (usually 0.5 mL of the syringe plug scale), otherwise repeat chip priming on a new chip. Another critical step is sample loading; avoid bubbles and, above all, quickly load samples following marker loading, otherwise reagents will wear out in the meantime, resulting in a wrong run.
Pause Point: at this point libraries can be directly normalized or stored at −20°C (stable for several weeks).

Note: prepared gel-dye mix is sufficient for five chips loading and can be used within 6 weeks from date of preparation.
Calculate concentration, normalize and pooling libraries
Use the following formula to calculate nM concentration of each Library sample:
   Q U B I T  c o n c e n t r a t i o n    n g   μ l        A v e r a g e  p e a k  o f  s m a l l  R N A s  o f  B i o a n a l y z e r  2100    x  660   ×  10 6  
Note: to select the correct Average peak of small RNAs please refer to the electropherogram and instructions shown in Figure 14[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig14].
Normalize libraries concentration by dilution in nuclease-free water until 2.0 nM and performing an intermediate step to 10 nM if libraries are concentrated more than 20 nM.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/732-Fig14.jpg
Figure 14. Selection of region of interest in 2100 Expert software
In 2100 Expert software, the region of interest can be selected in the sheet ‘Region Table’ (red rectangle; selection of the region should consider the main peak starting from the beginning of this peak to the beginning of the hump at 290–300 bp (vertical blue lines). Following this selection, the Average Size in bp will be returned (green rectangle).
Read Libraries concentration using QUBIT 3.0 after each intermediate or final dilution step and then proceed with further dilution or directly to pooling step.
Pool all normalized libraries using at least 3 μL of each diluted/normalized library.
Read again the concentration obtained from the libraries multiplexed pool using QUBIT 3.0 spectrofluorometer as previously described.
If needed adjust the final concentration of the libraries pool (2 nM) by further diluting it with nuclease-free water.

Critical: for libraries pooling, at least 3 μL of each library are required since smaller volumes result in a higher final concentration error. For libraries normalization consider an error range of ±0.3 nM (from 1.7 to 2.3 nM). A high variability between sample concentration could affect the equilibrium among different samples and the quality of small RNA sequencing (troubleshooting: problem 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.7]).
Sequencing sample sheet preparation
Timing: variable, depending on samples number
Create an Illumina Account on Illumina website (URL: https://login.illumina.com[href=https://login.illumina.com]).
Download the latest version of Illumina Experiment Manager (IEM) software (v1.19.1) at the following link: https://emea.support.illumina.com/sequencing/sequencing_software/experiment_manager/downloads.htmL[href=https://emea.support.illumina.com/sequencing/sequencing_software/experiment_manager/downloads.html].
Install Illumina Experiment Manager software following instructions.
Following installation, a folder named ‘Illumina’ will be generated in PC storage disk ‘C:Program Files (x86)’.
The ‘Illumina’ folder contains another folder named ‘Illumina Experiment Manager’ in which there are other sub-folders: ‘Applications’, ‘Genomes’, ‘IndexKits’ and ‘SamplePrepKits’.
In ‘SamplePrepKits’ folder, paste the ‘.txt’ file attached to this paper as Data S1[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/732-Mmc1.zip] (Deposited as a dataset on Mendeley Data with the https://doi.org/10.17632/7zcb24xbmy.1[href=https://doi.org/10.17632/7zcb24xbmy.1], URL: https://data.mendeley.com/datasets/7zcb24xbmy/1[href=https://data.mendeley.com/datasets/7zcb24xbmy/1]).
In ‘Applications’ folder, paste the ‘.txt’ file attached to this paper as Data S2[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/732-Mmc2.zip] (Deposited as a dataset on Mendeley Data with the https://doi.org/10.17632/74msx7j24b.1[href=https://doi.org/10.17632/74msx7j24b.1], URL: https://data.mendeley.com/datasets/74msx7j24b/1[href=https://data.mendeley.com/datasets/74msx7j24b/1]).
Open IEM software and select ‘Create Sample Plate’.
Select QIASEQ small RNA index adapters and press NEXT; rename the plate and press NEXT.
Rename your samples ID and assign to each sample the specific QIASEQ index used during amplification reaction; press finish.
Save the plate template in a folder easy to find (the suggested folder is hidden, and it is difficult to find).
Note: if you are going to sequence more than 96 samples you have to prepare more than one plate.

Critical: be careful not to use the same QIAGEN index for two or more samples that will be sequenced in the same pool/lane of the Flow Cell! IEM will return an error, and Sample Sheet will not be generated.
Re-open IEM software and select ‘Create Sample Sheet’
Then select ‘NovaSeq’ instrument and press NEXT
Choose ‘NovaSeq FASTQ only’ and press NEXT
Select the right Run parameters as indicated in Figure 15[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig15] and press NEXT:
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/732-Fig15.jpg
Figure 15. Sample Sheet parameters
Sample Sheet parameters to be set on Illumina Experiment Manager software.
Note: the option ‘Adapter Trimming’ indicates the trimming of the 3′Adapter, while ‘Adapter Trimming Read 2’ indicates the trimming of the 5′ Adapter.
Critical: if you plan to perform reads mapping and primary analysis through GeneGlobe QIAGEN online software, deselect ‘Adapter Trimming’, since QIAGEN software algorithm requires 3′ Adapter to recognize a correct processed ‘.fastq’ file. Indeed, if 3′Adapters sequences are previously trimmed, Gene Globe analysis generates an error, and the files cannot be further processed.
Press ‘Select Plate’: in the box at right all the samples you listed in the previously prepared plate will appear.
Select all the samples that will be sequenced in the same lane of the Flow Cell and select the lane; then press ‘Add selected samples’ and ‘Finish’.
Save the prepared Sample Sheet in ‘.csv’ format.
DO NOT OPEN the Sample Sheet in Excel when the software asks.
Note: if it is necessary to open and check the Sample Sheet, open it as ‘.txt’ file, otherwise it will not be recognized later on by NovaSeq 6000 instrument.
NovaSeq 6000 sncRNA sequencing using NovaSeq XP protocol
Timing: 1 day
The day before sequencing prepare and autoclave:
NaOH 1N in nuclease-free water.
Tris-HCl 400 mM pH 8.0 in nuclease-free water.

Tris-HCl 10 mM pH 8.5 in nuclease-free water.
Note: following protocol and data have been set up using SP flow cell. In order to optimize the protocol on the other flow cells (S1, S2 or S4), please refer to Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1].
table:files/protocols_protocol_732_12.csv
Thaw SBS and Cluster cartridges by placing them in a room temperature water bath (19°C–25°C) by submerging approximately halfway for 3 h.
Note: Use cartridges within 4 hours from the complete thawing.
Dilute libraries and PhyX control and pool them (the following steps refer to SP/S1 Flow cell loading concentration and volumes):
Thaw Library pool and PhiX 10 nM on ice.
Prepare 3 clean sterile 1.5 mL nuclease-free tubes.
Final loading concentration of Library pools is 175 pM.
Normalize/dilute Library pool as following (Final concentration: 0.95 nM): 9.5 μL of 2 nM Library pool+10.5 μL TrisHCl 10 mM pH 8.5.
Dilute 10 nM PhiX control until 0.25 nM (1:40) in TrisHCl 10 mM pH 8.5: 1 μL of 10 nM PhiX + 39 μL TrisHCl pH 8.5.
Mix 2.25 μL of diluted PhiX control with 15.75 μL of 0.95 nM normalized Library pool (PhiX control 6 %, Final Volume=18 μL).
Before to proceed to denaturation:
Thaw DPX1, DPX2 and DPX3 ExAmp reagents at room temperature for 15 min, then place them on ice.
Put Flow Cell at room temperature for 30 min before loading.
Note: use Flow Cell within 12 hours!
Denature libraries and PhyX pool:
Dilute 1N NaOH solution (to be diluted immediately before the use) until 0.2 N in nuclease-free water by mixing 2 μL of 1N NaOH with 8 μL of nuclease-free water.

Denature normalized/diluted Library pool (A and B) and PhiX control mix (Vol=18 μL) by adding 4 μL of 0.2 N NaOH to each mix; then cap the tube, briefly vortex and centrifuge 280×g for 1 min; allow the denaturation by incubating the sample 8 min at room temperature.
Add 5 μL of 400 mM TrisHCl pH 8.0; then cap the tube, briefly vortex and centrifuge 280×g for 1 min to obtain a final volume of 27 μL.
Place the denatured Library pool on ice.
Prepare Flow cell:
Place the NovaSeq Xp flow cell dock (see Key Resource Table) on a flat surface and keep it until the loading onto the instrument.
Wear a new clean pair of gloves not to contaminate the glass of flow cell dock and remove the clear plastic by peel opening the foil from the corner tab.
Remove the flow cell dock from the package by touching it by the sides not to touch the glass.
Inspect the dock is free from particulate; if particulate is present clean the surface with a lint-free alcohol wipe.
Invert the flow cell so that the top surface faces downward (with the movement indicated in Figure 16[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig16]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/732-Fig16.jpg
Figure 16. Flow cell inversion movement
Movement by which flow cell should be inverted.
Note: in this case, pool A contains n=28 libraries whose preparation has been performed using 5/18 μL of RNA; pool B contains n=28 libraries whose preparation has been performed using 5 μL of concentrated RNA from the total 18 μL of eluted RNA (test performed as reported in 3′ Adapter Ligation note).
Slip the outlet end of the flow cell under the bracket and place it onto the dock.

Load the Novaseq Xp manifold over the inlet end of the flow cell (be careful that the manifold fit securely).
Close the clamp to block flow cell and manifold and seal the gaskets.
Prepare ExAmp Master Mix:
Briefly vortex DPX1, DPX2 and DPX3 reagents and briefly centrifuge it.
In a sterile nuclease-free 1.7 mL tube mix: 126 μL of DPX1, 18 μL of DPX2 and 66 μL of DPX3 to obtain a final volume of 210 μL of ExAmp Master Mix (the mix could appear cloudy: it is normal).
Mix the reagent by slowly pipetting with a p200 micropipette and vortex 30 s.
Centrifuge the mix at 280×g for 1 min and immediately proceed to the loading.
Critical: DPX2 and even more DPX3 are very viscous reagents: be careful to take the right volume.
Load libraries onto the Flow Cell:
Add 63 μL ExAmp Master Mix in the tube containing 27 μL of denatured Library pool, vortex for 30 s and centrifuge at 280×g for 1 min.
Slowly load 80 μL of mixed Sample + ExAmp mix to each Novaseq Xp manifold well; avoid touching the filter.
Wait 2 min to allow the mixture to reach the opposite side of the lane (do not touch the flow cell!).
Note: the manifold wells are reversed, so be sure to load the right sample in the right well (as indicated in Figure 17[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig17]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/732-Fig17.jpg
Figure 17. Flow cell inverted order
Figure representing the inverted order of the two lanes of the flow cell.
Note: Do not tilt the flow cell.
Prepare thawed SBS and Cluster cartridges
Carefully inspect the cartridges that should be free of ice and water.
Invert the cartridges 10 times to mix reagents, and gently tap the cartridges to break all bubbles.
Load empty Library tube

Uncap the Library tube provided with the NovaSeq 6000 reagent kit.
Insert in position #8 the uncapped empty Library tube.
Set up a sequencing run
From the Home screen select Sequence and then select A or B (A+B to select a dual flow cell run).
Select OK to acknowledge the warning and open the flow cell door.
Load the flow cell onto the instrument
Inspect the flow cell stage that should be clean; if particulate is present clean the entire stage, including glass, fluidic interface and flow cell holder with alcohol and dry with lint-free wipe.
Remove the flow cell from the dock:
Open the clamp that blocks flow cell and manifold.
Carefully remove and discard the manifold.
Clean the flow cell with alcohol and dry with lint-free wipe if liquid drops are present.
Remove the flow cell by grasping it from the sides.
Clean the gaskets (without touching them) with alcohol and dry with lint-free wipe if liquid drops are present.
Invert the flow cell as previously described in Figure 16[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig16].
Clean the dock with alcohol and dry with lint-free wipe if particulate is present.
Align the flow cell over the four raised clamps and place it on the flow cell stage.
Select Close Flow Cell door (the flow cell ID will appear on the screen).
Load the SBS and Cluster Cartridges:
Open the liquid compartment doors and then open the reagent chiller door.
Load the cartridges (the SBS cartridge with the gray label into the left position, and the cluster cartridges with the orange label into the right position).
Side the drawer into the chiller and close the reagent chiller door (The Library tube ID will appear on the screen).
Load the buffer cartridges and start run:
Pull the metal handle to open the buffer drawer.

Place the buffer cartridge into the buffer drawer so that the Illumina label faces the front of the drawer and align the cartridge.
Select the button Log In to sign in to BaseSpace Sequence Hub.
To send run data to BaseSpace Sequence Hub for remote monitoring and data analysis, select Run Monitoring and Storage (this option requires a Sample Sheet).
Enter your BaseSpace Sequence Hub username and password and select Sign In.
If prompted, select a workgroup to upload run data to and select Run Setup.
Select a workflow type (in this case NovaSeq Xp) and rename the run.
Enter the number of cycles and index length. Read1 76 cycles Index1 8 Read2 0 Index2 0
Select Advanced options, select Sample Sheet and Browse to upload your ready Sample Sheet (.csv).
Select Start Run and wait about 5 min until the pre-run check is completed.
Note: although the sequencing run is 1×75, when setting the parameters in the instrument, one more cycle should be considered; indeed, one more cycle is required for instrument phasing and prephasing calculations (Kircher et al., 2011[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib11]).
Critical: In order to correctly perform data analysis using BaseSpace and then GeneGlobe QIAGEN miRNA quantification:
Use Illumina Experiment Manager (IEM) to generate the Sample Sheet.
Rename the Sample Sheet as “SampleSheet.csv” in order to be recognized by BaseSpace.
Do not open the file using excel or other software. If needed, use only notepad.
Be sure to include the sequences of 5′ or 3′ Adapter you want to be Trimmed out by BaseSpace.

Since Gene Globe QIAGEN miRNA quantification online tool have a Trimming tool included and instructed to trim out 3′ Adapters, if your FastQ files contain reads already trimmed out for both adapters, the algorithm generates an error (“>95% Reads of Sample X did not have custom sequencing adapter”) and does not proceed to the analysis.
Single assay validation of selected miRNAs
Timing: variable, depending on number of miRNAs to validate
Since sncRNA sequencing analysis required 5 out of 18 μL of total eluted RNA extracted from plasma samples, the same RNA aliquot can be used to perform the subsequent validation. The following validation protocol is based on the use of Stem-Loop RT Primers and Taqman Assays RT-Real Time PCR (Chen et al., 2005[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3]).
Perform Multiplex Custom miRNAs Reverse Transcriptase (RT) reaction:
Prepare custom Stem-Loop RT primer pool by diluting each 5× RT primer 1:100 (ex: 5 μL of each primer in a total volume of 500 μL of TE 1×; 5 μL of primer 1 + 5 μL of primer 2 + 5 μL of primer 3 + 485 μL of TE 1×) in TE 1×. Up to 96 RT Stem-Loop primers can be multiplexed.
Prepare the RT reaction mix on ice in a 1.5 mL tube as follows:
table:files/protocols_protocol_732_13.csv
Mix thoroughly and briefly spin down the tube.
In a 0.2 or 0.1 mL tube (depending on the thermal cycler), add 12 μL of RT reaction mix into each tube and add 3 μL of total RNA per reaction into each tube containing RT reaction mix for a total reaction volume of 15 μL.
Resuspend and briefly spin down the samples. Perform RT at the following thermal cycling conditions:
table:files/protocols_protocol_732_14.csv

Important: include a negative control reaction (3 μL nuclease-free water reaction) in order to evaluate potential cross-primers effects and external/carry-over contaminations (troubleshooting: problem 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.9]).
Perform Custom miRNAs PreAmplification:
Prepare custom PreAmp primer pool by diluting each 20× TM primer 1:100 (ex: 5 μL of each primer in a total volume of 500 μL of TE 1×) in TE1×. Up to 96 TM primers can be multiplexed.
Prepare the reaction mix in a 1.5 mL tube as follows:
table:files/protocols_protocol_732_15.csv
In a 0.2 or 0.1 mL tube (depending on the thermal cycler), transfer 22.5 μL of the PreAmp reaction mix and 2.5 μL of each RT product into each well or tube.
Start run according to the following thermal cycler conditions:
table:files/protocols_protocol_732_16.csv
Remove the samples from the thermal cycler and put on ice.
Dilute samples 1:8 by adding 175 μL of 0.1× TE pH 8.0 to each tube. This is the diluted PreAmp product (Final Volume = 200 μL) that can be used for qRT Real-Time PCR.
Important: include a negative control reaction (2.5 μL nuclease-free water reaction) in order to evaluate potential cross-primers effects and external/carry-over contaminations independent from RT reactions.
Perform Real Time PCR:
Prepare a mix for each microRNA as follows:
table:files/protocols_protocol_732_17.csv
Load 2 μL of PreAmplified cDNA (diluted 1:8) in each well of a 96 well plate in duplicate.
Add 18 μL of the previously prepared mix.
Start run according to the following thermal cycling conditions:
table:files/protocols_protocol_732_18.csv
Note: if a higher output is needed for low expressed microRNAs, a higher amount of cDNA can be loaded considering that: to obtain 1 Ct decrease you need to load 2× cDNA; to obtain 3.32 Ct decrease you need to load 10× cDNA.
Note: we used a Viia7 qPCR instrument (Thermo Fisher), by performing a fast run protocol.
Note: always consider to add a No Template Control (NTC) sample, loading 2 μL of nuclease-free water (instead of sample) and 18 μL of mix.
